references.B84GRE01USGP: Gregory, P.T., and R.W. Campbell. 1984. The Reptiles of British Columbia. Royal B.C. Mus. Handb. 102pp.
references.B97COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1997. Standard common and current scientific names for North American amphibians and reptiles. Fourth edition. SSAR Herpetological Circular No. 25.
references.B99HAMUSGP: Hammerson, G. 1999.  Amphibians and reptiles in Colorado. Second edition. University Press of Colorado and Colorado Division of Wildlife.Niwot, Colorado, USA.
references.A01GOL01USGP: Goldberg, S.R. 2001. Reproduction in the Night Snake, Hypsiglena torquata (Serpentes: Colubridae), from Arizona. Texas J. Sci. 53:107-114.
references.B83NUS01NAUS: Nussbaum, R. A., and E. D. Brodie, Jr. and R. M. Storm. 1983. Amphibians and Reptiles of the Pacific Northwest. University Press of Idaho. 332 pp.
references.B02STJ01USGP: St. John, A. D. 2002. Reptiles of the Northwest: Alaska to California; Rockies to the Coast. Lone Pine Publishing. Alberta, Canada.
references.B03STE01USGP: Stebbins, R.C. 2003. A field guide to western reptiles and amphibians.  Third Edition. Houghton Mifflin, Boston.
references.A86DIL01USGP: Diller, L. V., and R. L. Wallace. 1986. Aspects of the life history and ecology of the desert night snake, HYPSIGLENA TORQUATA DESERTICOLA: Colubridae, in southwestern Idaho. Southwest. Nat. 31:55-64.
references.W12NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.A08MUL01USGP: Mulcahy, D.G. 2008. Phylogeography and species boundaries of the western North American Nightsnake (Hypsiglena torquata): Revisiting the subspecies concept. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution 46:1095-1115.

habitat_description:
The range of the desert night snake encompasses areas from south-central British Columbia through Washington, Oregon, southern Idaho, Nevada, Utah, eastern California, western Colorado, Arizona, northeastern Baja California, and northwestern Mexico (Mulcahy 2008). The habitat is mostly characterized by bare rock, talus, scree, desert, grassland, savanna, shrubland, chaparral, and conifer and hardwood woodland.

This species is known to burrow in or using soil, fallen logs, and leaf litter. Prolonged periods of inactivity are spent under rocks, in crevices, or underground. In Idaho, researchers have found individuals under surface rocks in the spring, but not as many during the summer (Diller and Wallace 1986).

The habitats of preference include arid and semiarid plains, canyons, and hillsides. These areas are predominately rocky, dissected terrain composed of sandy and gravelly soils (Hammerson 1999; Stebbins 2003).

SW	-The sparsely vegetated areas of this species’ range provide cover in the form of rocks, crevices, loose (non-compacted soils), leaf litter, and fallen logs.

From Crothers et al 2012 regarding H torquata (modeled by ReGAP efforts) and 3 modeled species "The nominal species H. torquata is now restricted to Mexico, three described forms occur in the USA, and the undescribed form is endemic to the Cochise Filter Barrier area of southeastern Arizona and associated New Mexico"
